{{pp|small=yes}} {{Redirect|Tamang|the language|Tamang language}} {{Multiple issues| {{POV|date=August 2016}} {{refimprove|date=August 2016}} }} {{infobox ethnic group |group = Tamang
तामाङ | image = | population = 1,539,830
{{flagcountry|Nepal}} | languages = [[Tamang language]] | religions = 90% [[File:Dharma wheel.svg|24px]] [[Buddhism]]
10% other (including [[File:Om.svg|23px]] [[Hinduism]]) |}} [[File:Tamang Woman 2.JPG|upright|thumb|A Tamang Woman]] [[File:Buddhist Lama of the Tamang People, Tistung, Nepal.jpg|upright|thumb|Buddhist Lama of the Tamang People, [[Tistung Deurali|Tistung]], [[Nepal]]]] The '''Tamang''' {{bo-textonly|ཏ་མང}} ([[Devnagari]]: तामाङ; ''tāmāng'') are the largest [[Tibeto-Burman]] ethnic group within Nepal and traditionally Buddhist by religion. Constituting 5.6% of the national population at over 1.3 million in 2001, increasing to 1,539,830 as of 2011 census,{{cite web |url=https://publications.theseus.fi/bitstream/handle/10024/73036/Ghimire_Mahesh.pdf?sequence=1 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-12-22 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304082038/https://publications.theseus.fi/bitstream/handle/10024/73036/Ghimire_Mahesh.pdf?sequence=1 |archivedate=2016-03-04 |df= }} yet contested.note from: http://thebluespace.com/the-tamang-people/{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=Tabletop123 |fix-attempted=yes }}, "these figures are contested by the Tamang themselves as some had written Lama or their family name on the census form were not counted as Tamang and many others have in the past changed their caste in order to escape the caste limitations placed upon them." Tamangs are also a significant majority in [[Sikkim]] and [[Darjeeling District]] of [[West Bengal]], [[India]] as permanent settlers;{{cite web |url=http://thebluespace.com/the-tamang-people/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150706060655/http://thebluespace.com/the-tamang-people/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2015-07-06 |title=The Tamang People - The Blue Space Guides Nepal |publisher=Thebluespace.com |date=2014-06-20 |accessdate=2015-12-23 }}{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uLfE8HGwdIMC&pg=PA277|title=Archived copy|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160427035600/https://books.google.com/books?id=uLfE8HGwdIMC&pg=PA277|archivedate=2016-04-27|deadurl=no|accessdate=2015-12-23|df=}} Emergent North-East : A Way Forward By H. C. Sadangi their languages are the fifth most spoken in Nepal (note all Tamang languages are not mutually intelligible). They are one of the Tibetan migrant who come to Nepal.{{cite web |url=http://www.nefin.org.np/hppics/10789_Nepal%20Tamang%20Ghedung%20Kabhre,%20Report%20on%20Socio-Economic%20Status%20of%20Tamang-%20Kavre.doc |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130312053215/http://www.nefin.org.np//hppics/10789_Nepal%20Tamang%20Ghedung%20Kabhre,%20Report%20on%20Socio-Economic%20Status%20of%20Tamang-%20Kavre.doc |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-03-12 |title=Report on Socio-Economic Status of Tamang–Kavre |publisher=Nefin.org.np |date= |accessdate=2015-12-23 }} Peculiar to Tamang people are complex marriage restrictions within the community. == Status == {{quotebox|width=25em| bgcolor=#B0C4DE|align=left|1/3 of all deaths were among Tamang people, and roughly 2/3 of the 600,000 structures completely destroyed were in Tamang dominant areas.{{cite web |url=http://www.nepalitimes.com/blogs/thebrief/2015/07/05/the-tamang-epicentre/ |title=The Brief » Blog Archive » The Tamang epicentre |publisher=Nepali Times |date=2015-07-05 |accessdate=2015-12-23 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151128211844/http://www.nepalitimes.com/blogs/thebrief/2015/07/05/the-tamang-epicentre/ |archivedate=2015-11-28 |df= }} '''It is the poverty, neglect and outright discrimination against Tamangs that makes them even more vulnerable to disasters like earthquakes, landslides and floods'''—Anthropologist Mukta Singh Lama.}} In Nepal, until 1950, Tamangs were neither accepted into government posts, whether administrative, judicial or political, nor allowed to accept foreign employment, serving as a labour pool for the ruling class. But nowadays, Tamangs are highly respected as Buddhist Monks (priest) as [[rinpoche]], khempo. In many Tamang Villages, there is still a tradition of sending the second son to study Buddhism and preferably to remain in the Monastery, and serve as a Buddhist Monk throughout his life. The Nepal Government has considered that the empowerment of Tamang community is essential to in order to increase the living standard of the people. On August 3 the Nepalese parliament adopted a bill amending the Civil Service Act 1993. The amendments provide reservations for disadvantaged groups by allocating 45 percent of the jobs in the bureaucracy to these groups. Today they inhabit the borders of Nepal and Tibet, due to marginalization from Kathmandu, and are among the groups hardest hit by the [[April 2015 Nepal earthquake]]. ==Political participation== Tamangs are represented by [[Tamsaling Rastriya Mukti Morcha]] and [[Tamsaling Nepal Rastriya Dal]], neither of which holds any seats in Parliament. The umbrella group [[Mongol National Organisation]] supports self-determination and works against said discrimination not just for Tamangs but for all Mongoloid groups in Nepal. Mongol National is against conversion to Hinduism of non-Hindus, but it holds no official parliamentary vote. [[Federal Limbuwan State Council]] (FLSC) also works towards similar goals for [[self-determination]] for the [[Kirati people]]s, who co-mingle with Tamangs, citing a reneged treaty with Kathmandu for autonomy.Chemjong, Iman Singh (2003). History and Culture of Kirat People (4th ed.). Kathmandu: Kirat Yakthung Chumlung. {{ISBN|99933-809-1-1}}. The associated [[Sanghiya Limbuwan Party]] has participated in calling [[bandh|banda]] during the [[2015 Nepal blockade]],{{cite web |url=http://thehimalayantimes.com/nepal/sanghiya-limbuwan-party-calls-indefinite-eastern-region-bandh/ |title=Sanghiya Limbuwan Party calls indefinite Eastern Region bandh |publisher=The Himalayan Times |date=2015-09-04 |accessdate=2015-12-23 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151223090948/http://thehimalayantimes.com/nepal/sanghiya-limbuwan-party-calls-indefinite-eastern-region-bandh/ |archivedate=2015-12-23 |df= }} nevertheless international press had not only failed to take note of their ''bandh'', but even pretended not to notice their very existence and instead focused intently on 4 party India-backed Madhesi Morcha actions, geopolitical concerns with [[China]], as [[Limbuwan]] also opposes both the Madhesi goals as well as Kathmandu's domination.{{cite web |author=Om Astha Rai |url=http://nepalitimes.com/regular-columns/As-It-Happens/Nepal-needs-to-look-within-and-mend-fences,603 |title=Look south | As It Happens |publisher=Nepali Times |date= |accessdate=2015-12-23 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151223143548/http://nepalitimes.com/regular-columns/As-It-Happens/Nepal-needs-to-look-within-and-mend-fences,603 |archivedate=2015-12-23 |df= }} However, there is rationale to India and Western nation's denial of information about Limbuwan actions during the fuel blockade, in the 1980s, a violent [[Gorkhaland]] movement within [[India]] was led by the prominent Tamang [[Subhas Ghising]] to which India had viewed as a security threat due to the proximity of [[Siliguri Corridor|India's chicken neck]]. [[Madan Tamang]], a Tamang-Indian politician, and proponent for Gorkhaland statehood, was assassinated in 2010, with [[West Bengal]] government placing blame on another Gorkhaland political party, in effect weakening the movement. [[Gorkhaland Territorial Administration]] was then created in place of statehood in [[India]], nevertheless across the border, ethnic discrimination issues regarding the numerous Mongoloid groups (who have taken part in each other's politics) are left unresolved within Nepal. In 2017 [[Binay Tamang]] was appointed as the Chairperson of GTA.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/gta-reconstituted-rebel-gjm-leader-tamang-is-chairperson/article19724174.ece|title=GTA reconstituted, rebel GJM leader Tamang is chairperson|date=2017-09-21|work=The Hindu|access-date=2018-02-28|others=Special Correspondent, Special Correspondent|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180228230723/http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/gta-reconstituted-rebel-gjm-leader-tamang-is-chairperson/article19724174.ece|archivedate=2018-02-28|df=}} ==Religion== [[File:Tamang Gompa, Jorpati (02).jpg|thumb|Tamang Gompa, Jorpati (02)]] The religion is considered by Tamangs as [[Nyingma]] tradition of [[Vajrayana]] Buddhism, the earliest form of Buddhism to come to Nepal/Tibet with Padmasambhava, and due to geopolitical focus on Tibet, Tamangs hold their beliefs are also ''largely ignored'' by Western scholars. Tamang have [[gompa]]s (monasteries) in every sizeable village. Every family has their special Buddhist Yidam and book to practice every morning. The Tamangs retain ''jhankris'' (shamans) in addition to their [[Lama clan (Tamang)]] (priests), the latter whose surnames are also Lama. Additionally there exists the honorific term [[Lama (honorific)]], assigned to all Tamang regardless of kinship clan (''swagen bhai''). This is not to be confused with [[Lama]] of Tibet or the [[Sherpa people|Sherpa]] Lama surname and clan. These jhankris perform certain rites such as trances and sacrifices to alleviate problems or assure good fortune. ==Etymology== ''Tamang'' was derived from the word ''Tamag'', where ''Ta'' means “horse”, and ''Mag'' means “soldier”.{{Cite news|url=https://advancedadventures.wordpress.com/2015/01/05/tamang-people-of-nepal/|title=Who actually are the Tamang People? An Insight into Indigenous Tribe of Nepal|date=2015-01-05|work=Chronicles of ADVENTURE TRAVEL|access-date=2018-02-28|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180301044744/https://advancedadventures.wordpress.com/2015/01/05/tamang-people-of-nepal/|archive-date=2018-03-01|dead-url=yes|df=}} ==Culture== ===Festivals=== '''Sonam Lhochhar''' is the main festival of the Tamangs and is celebrated in the month on Magh (February - March).{{Cite web|url=http://streetnepal.com/sonam-lhochhar-celebrated/|title=Sonam Lhochhar celebrated {{!}} Street Nepal|website=streetnepal.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-28|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160816080424/http://streetnepal.com/sonam-lhochhar-celebrated/|archivedate=2016-08-16|df=}} It is celebrated to welcome the Tamang new year. Colorful flags, printed Buddhist [[mantra]] cloths are put up in various places in villages and towns. The Tamangs have a genre of music called called " ''[[Tamang Selo]]"'' that is performed with the ''[[Damphu_drum|Damplu]]'' instrument, also known as Damphoo Dance, having a brisk movement and rhythmic beat specific to the Tamangs. The second most important festival is '''Saga Dawa''' (Buddha Jayanti) and is celebrated as a religious festival.{{Cite news|url=https://advancedadventures.wordpress.com/2015/01/05/tamang-people-of-nepal/|title=Who actually are the Tamang People? An Insight into Indigenous Tribe of Nepal|date=2015-01-05|work=Chronicles of ADVENTURE TRAVEL|access-date=2018-02-28|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180301044744/https://advancedadventures.wordpress.com/2015/01/05/tamang-people-of-nepal/|archive-date=2018-03-01|dead-url=yes|df=}} [[Dashain]] and [[Tihar (festival)]] is also celebrated with much enthusiasm by Tamangs. ===Livelihood=== Most Tamangs are farmers, engaged in [[agriculture]]. Due to the lack of irrigation at higher altitudes, their crops are often limited to corn, millet, wheat, barley, and potatoes. They often supplement their farming income with manual labour. Due to the discrimination experienced by the Tamang people in the past, they have remained on the whole poorly educated, and the majority have been limited to working as farmers, mountain trekking, portering, and driving in Kathmandu. They also work in manufacture of Tibetan rugs, Thankas (Tibetan painting), driving and labour. As far as farming is concerned, Tamang are dependent on rainfall and do not employ modern machinery. === Music === [[File:Navneet-Aditya-Waiba-Live.jpg|left|thumb|Navneet Aditya Waiba|260x260px]] [[File:Hira Devi Waiba.jpg|alt=Hira Devi Waiba - A Tamang and Pioneer of Nepali Folk Songs.|thumb|Hira Devi Waiba - A Tamang and Pioneer of Nepali Folk Songs.]] Tamangs are known in Nepali Art/Music of Nepal. Some prominent names are: singer- [[Hira Devi Waiba]],{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraphindia.com/1110120/jsp/siliguri/story_13466851.jsp|title=The Telegraph - Calcutta (Kolkata) {{!}} North Bengal & Sikkim {{!}} Hira Devi dies of burn injuries|website=www.telegraphindia.com|access-date=2018-03-11}}singer- [[Kunti Moktan]],{{Cite news|url=http://dhakatopi.com/kunti-moktan|title=Kunti Moktan|access-date=2018-03-11|language=en}} [[Navneet Aditya Waiba]], [[Phiroj Shyangden]], [[Prashant Tamang]],{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.in/2017/06/21/indian-idol-winner-prashant-tamang-is-the-rallying-voice-of-the_a_22494541/|title=Indian Idol Winner Prashant Tamang Is The Rallying Voice Of The Gorkhaland Protests|date=2017-06-21|work=Huffington Post India|access-date=2018-03-11|language=en-IN}}[[Zenisha Moktan]],{{Cite web|url=http://nepaliactress.com/tag/zenisha-moktan/|title=Zenisha Moktan {{!}} Nepali Actress|website=nepaliactress.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-11}}[[Nima Rumba]],{{Cite news|url=http://www.myrepublica.com/archive/29310/Nima-Rumba-&-Style|title=Nima Rumba & Style|work=My Republica|access-date=2018-03-11|language=en}}[[Aruna Lama]],{{Cite news|url=http://bossnepal.com/melody-queen-aruna-lama/|title=Melody queen Aruna Lama|work=Boss Nepal|access-date=2018-03-11|language=en-US}}[[Karma Yonzon]], [[Gopal Yonjan]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.hamrokalakar.com/gopal-yonzon|title=Gopal Yonzon Biography {{!}} Hamro Kalakar|last=Kalakar|first=Hamro|website=www.hamrokalakar.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-11}}, Prem Lopchan. ===Kinship clans=== Thars ([[Tamang language]]:''Swagen Bhai'') are exogamous clans with complex intermarriage restrictions. There are over 39 listed ''swagen bhai'' in one study. ==Origins and history== Tamangs are coming from tibet and have long inhabited Kathmandu Valley and the hills of Nepal in general, yet the origins of Tamang are exactly from upper tibet( around govi desert ) according to archiological study done by Dr. anatoly yakoblave shetenko, yet they believe they are indigenous to the area had once ruled lhasa. They have beliefs that they have been descended from bhote which is called as [[tibet]] in modern district.Tamang found in sikkim also ==Trekking and tourism== Tamang villages are often visited on Nepal's numerous trekking routes, one being labelled ''Tamang Heritage Trail''.{{cite web |author=Post Report |url=http://kathmandupost.ekantipur.com/printedition/news/2015-07-30/tamang-heritage-trail-reopens-after-quake.html |title=The Kathmandu Post :: Tamang Heritage Trail reopens after quake |publisher=Kathmandupost.ekantipur.com |date= |accessdate=2015-12-23 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208065012/http://kathmandupost.ekantipur.com/printedition/news/2015-07-30/tamang-heritage-trail-reopens-after-quake.html |archivedate=2015-12-08 |df= }} They also work as porters and the chances are that the porters and guides on a Trek are more likely to be a Tamang than an actual [[Sherpa people|Sherpa]]. == See also == [[Tamang language]] [[Tamang Selo]] [[Hira Devi Waiba]] [[Navneet Aditya Waiba]] ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.everyculture.com/South-Asia/Gurkha.html/ Gurkha], tamang Gurkha * {{cite web|url=http://www.everestnews.com/stories004sec4002/everesttamangs11263002one.htm|title=Introduction to Ethnic Groups – The Tamangs: The Unknown Mount Everest Climbers|website= EverestNews.com|accessdate=4 January 2013}} {{Ethnic groups in Nepal}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Buddhist communities]] [[Category:Sino-Tibetan-speaking people]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Nepal]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Northeast India]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in South Asia]]

{{See also|Proposed reforms of mass surveillance by the United States}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox civil conflict | title = The Day We Fight Back | partof = [[Aftermath of the global surveillance disclosure]] | image = [[Image:The Day We Fight Back - banner.jpg|300px]] | caption = The banner of The Day We Fight Back | date = February 11, 2014 | place = Online plus physical protests in various locals | coordinates = | causes = [[Snowden leaks]], [[Global surveillance]] | goals = * Strengthen and pass [[USA Freedom Act]] * Oppose the [[FISA Improvements Act]] * Enact protections for non-Americans | methods = Website banners and various actions | status = | result = * 90,474 calls and 188,198 emails to Congress.{{citation needed|date=February 2014}} * Primary goal of passage of the [[USA Freedom Act]] incomplete. | side1 = | side2 = | side3 = | leadfigures1 = Planning: *[[Sina Khanifar]] *[[David Segal (politician)|David Segal]] *[[Rainey Reitman]] *Thomas Davis{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/EFF/status/433381484016070657 |title=Major thanks to our friends @sinak, @demandprogress, and @neutralthoughts [(Thomas Davis)]. #TheDayWeFightBack wouldn't have been possible without them |publisher=[[Twitter]] |author=EFF |date=February 12, 2014 |accessdate=24 February 2014}} Along with: [[Demand Progress]], [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]], [[Fight for the Future]], [[Free Press (organization)|Free Press organization]], [[Reddit]], [[Mozilla]], and [[Boing Boing]]. | leadfigures2 = Notable Participants: * [[Facebook]] * [[AOL]] * [[Twitter]] * [[LinkedIn]] * [[Yahoo]] * [[Wikia]] * [[Google]]{{cite web|url=https://publicpolicy.googleblog.com/2014/02/its-time-to-reform-government.html|title=It's time to reform government surveillance laws|publisher=}} | leadfigures3 = | howmany1 = | howmany2 = | howmany3 = | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties3 = | fatalities = | injuries = | arrests = | detentions = | charged = | fined = | casualties_label = | notes = Motto: The Day We Fight Back against mass surveillance
{{url|thedaywefightback.org}} }} '''The Day We Fight Back''' was a one-day global protest against [[Global surveillance disclosures (2013–present)|mass surveillance]] by the US [[National Security Agency]] (NSA),{{cite news |url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/2086880/advocacy-groups-plan-day-of-protest-against-nsa-surveillance.html |title=Advocacy groups plan day of protest against NSA surveillance |work=[[PC World]] |first=Grant |last=Gross |date=January 10, 2014 |accessdate=January 14, 2014}}{{cite news |url=http://www.mintpressnews.com/activists-announce-day-to-fight-back-against-nsa/176890/ |title=Activists Announce Day To 'Fight Back' Against NSA |publisher=MintPress News |first=Katie |last=Rucke |date=January 14, 2014 |accessdate=January 14, 2014}}{{cite news |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/reddit-mozilla-others-protest-nsa-spying-honor-aaron-swartz-day-we-fight-back-1538148 |title=Reddit, Mozilla And Others To Protest NSA Spying, Honor Aaron Swartz On 'The Day We Fight Back' |work=[[International Business Times]] |first=Eric |last=Brown |date=January 14, 2014 |accessdate=January 14, 2014}} the [[Government of the United Kingdom|UK]] [[GCHQ]],{{cite news |last=Solon|first=Olivia|title=Don't Spy On Us: it's time to hold politicians to account for mass surveillance|url=https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2014-02/11/dont-spy-on-us|accessdate=2014-02-11|newspaper=Wired UK|date=2014-02-11}}{{cite news |last=Albanesius|first=Chloe|title=The Day We Fight Back: What You Need to Know|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2453028,00.asp|work=PC Magazine|accessdate=11 February 2014}} and the other [[Five Eyes]] partners involved in global surveillance. The "digital protest" took place on February 11, 2014 with more than 6,000 participating websites,{{cite news |last=Sparkes|first=Matthew|title=Reddit and Tumblr among websites protesting NSA surveillance|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/news/10630928/Reddit-and-Tumblr-among-websites-protesting-NSA-surveillance.html|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=11 February 2014|location=London|date=February 11, 2014}} which primarily took the form of webpage banner-advertisements that read, "Dear Internet, we're sick of complaining about the NSA. We want new laws that curtail online surveillance. Today we fight back." Organizers hoped lawmakers would be made aware "that there's going to be ongoing public pressure until these reforms are instituted."{{cite news |last=Siner|first=Emily|title=The Internet Flexes Political Muscle With Anti-NSA Protest|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/alltechconsidered/2014/02/11/274901562/the-internet-flexes-political-muscle-with-anti-nsa-protest|publisher=NPR|accessdate=11 February 2014}} The protest was announced on January 10, 2014, by the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] (EFF). Other early organizers included digital rights groups such as [[Fight for the Future]], and [[Free Press (organization)|Free Press]], as well as social media website [[Reddit]], [[Firefox]] producer [[Mozilla]], collaborative blogging website [[Boing Boing]], and populist advocacy group '"The Other 98%". According to the official website, the protest asked U.S. "legislators to oppose the [[FISA Improvements Act]], support the [[USA Freedom Act]], and enact protections for non-Americans."{{cite web |url=https://thedaywefightback.org/ |title=Today, February 11th, 2014 is The Day We Fight Back against mass surveillance |accessdate=2014-02-11}}{{cite web|url=http://www.valuewalk.com/2014/02/data-spying-feb-11-to-become-the-day-we-fight-back/ |title=Data Spying: Feb. 11 To Become "The Day We Fight Back" |publisher=Valuewalk.com|date=2014-02-04 |accessdate=2014-02-11}}{{update after|2014|02|12}} Protest organizers said roughly 96,000 calls were placed to members of Congress and 555,000 "pro-privacy emails" were sent via the website.{{cite news |last=Damon|first=Poeter|title=The Day We Fight Back Generates Nearly 100K Calls To Congress|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2453387,00.asp|accessdate=17 February 2014|work=PC Magazine}} ==Purpose== The Day We Fight Back was intended as a day of "worldwide solidarity" in protest against NSA surveillance. It was at once an action against censorship and surveillance, and a commemoration of late "open-Internet activist" [[Aaron Swartz]]. In the US, a main goal of the protest was to encourage passage of the [[USA Freedom Act]], a bill that seeks to reign in telephone data collection. Additionally, the banner urged people to call Congress and voice opposition to the [[FISA Improvements Act]], which the ACLU called "a dream come true for the NSA" that would "codify the NSA's unconstitutional call-records program and allow bulk collection of location data from mobile phone users."{{cite news |last=Wagstaff|first=Keith|title=Reddit, Tumblr and More Protest NSA With 'Day We Fight Back'|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/internet/reddit-tumblr-more-protest-nsa-day-we-fight-back-n26416|publisher=NBC News|accessdate=10 February 2014}} Outside the US, the goal was similar. A ''Guardian'' op-ed described the activists' objective globally as "to push authorities toward policies favoring liberty and privacy".{{cite news |last=Gilmore|first=Dan|title=Get ready: the day we fight back against mass surveillance is coming|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/feb/06/nsa-fighting-back-against-surveillence-state|work=The Guardian|accessdate=9 February 2014}} Organizers posted to their website: "Together we will push back against powers that seek to observe, collect, and analyze our every digital action.Together, we will make it clear that such behavior is not compatible with democratic governance. Together, if we persist, we will win this fight." Rainey Reitman, director of activism at the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation|EFF]], said, "The idea is to really harness the outrage of the Internet community in speaking out in one big voice on Feb. 11." The protest comes a month after President Obama made a surveillance reform speech introducing his proposed changes to the collection of US citizens' data. Critics said the reformations wouldn't be "nearly enough".g{{cite news |last=Hattem|first=Julian|title="The idea is to really harness the outrage of the Internet community in speaking out in one big voice on Feb. 11," said Rainey Reitman, the director of activism at the Electronic Frontier Foundation|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/hillicon-valley/technology/197859-thousands-of-sites-to-protest-nsa-spying |publisher=The Hill|accessdate=10 February 2014}} Organizers compared the February protest with the SOPA protest two years prior, saying, "Today we face a different threat, one that undermines the Internet and the notion that any of us live in a genuinely free society". The threats were 'International counterparts like [[Five Eyes]] and [[Tempora]], mass surveillance, and programs such as [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]], Canada's [[Communications Security Establishment Canada|CSEC]] airport monitoring activities'.{{cite news |last=Rickwood|first=Lee|title=Protesting mass surveillance: Canada called to join The Day We Fight Back|url=http://www.calgaryherald.com/technology/Protesting+mass+surveillance+Canada+called+join+Fight+Back/9468059/story.html|work=Calgary Herald|accessdate=17 February 2014}} ==Background== === Promotion === The Day We Fight Back was promoted in a trailer for an upcoming documentary about Aaron Swartz, currently titled ''The Internet's Own Boy''.{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/01/11/aaron-swartz-documentary_n_4578257.html |title=Aaron Swartz Documentary Clip Reveals Activist's Thoughts On NSA, Pushes Day Of Action |publisher=[[The Huffington Post]] |first=Joanna |last=Zelman |date=January 11, 2014 |accessdate=January 15, 2014}} In the clip, the late activist comments on [[Global surveillance|mass surveillance]]: "It is shocking to think that the accountability is so lax that they don't even have sort of basic statistics about how big the spying programme is. If the answer is, 'Oh, we're spying on so many people we can't possibly even count them,' then that's an awful lot of people." Five months after Swartz's death, the scale of a vast global surveillance program would be [[Global surveillance disclosures (2013–present)|revealed]] in great detail through the release of top-secret NSA documents by [[Edward Snowden]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/jan/11/aaron-swartz-death-first-anniversary |title=Hacking of MIT website marks first anniversary of Aaron Swartz's death |work=[[The Guardian]] |first=Martin |last=Pengelly |date=January 11, 2014 |accessdate=January 15, 2014}} [[Amy Goodman]] of [[Democracy Now!]] promoted The Day We Fight Back in an opinion article in the ''[[Athens News]]'', noting Swartz's role in the digital rights movement calling for "another fight for the freedom of the Internet" without him.{{cite news |url=http://www.athensnews.com/ohio/article-41560-aaron-swartz-the-life-we-lost-and-the-day-we-fight-back.html |title=Aaron Swartz: The life we lost and the day we fight back |work=Athens News |first=Amy |last=Goodman |date=January 26, 2014}} ===Reddit "Ask Me Anything" === Comparing the opposition to surveillance with the previous defeat of SOPA, in which Demand Progress and Aaron Swartz had been deeply involved, the organizers took to Reddit and called for a month of activities culminating in the February 11 "day of action"{{cite web |url=https://www.reddit.com/r/IAmA/comments/1uw05k/aaron_swartz_passed_away_a_year_ago_tomorrow_we/ |title=Aaron Swartz passed away a year ago tomorrow. We are Cory Doctorow, Brian Knappenberger, Peter Eckersley (EFF), and David Segal (Demand Progress) here to talk about Aaron and a protest we're organizing on 02/11 in his honor. Ask us anything |publisher=Reddit |first1=Cory |last1=Doctorow |first2=Brian |last2=Knappenberger |first3=Peter |last3=Eckersley |first4=David |last4=Segal |date=January 10, 2014}}{{cite news |last=Wolfgang|first=Ben|title=Obama faces 'day of action' to protest NSA reforms|url=http://p.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/jan/16/obama-faces-day-action-protest-nsa-reforms/|work=The Washington Times|accessdate=10 February 2014}} In an "Ask Me Anything" (AMA) discussion held on January 10, several organizers announced the action and fielded user questions, saying their purpose was to answer questions "about Aaron and a protest we're organizing on 02/11 in his honor". Those participating were [[Cory Doctorow]] of [[BoingBoing]]; [[Brian Knappenberger]], who made the films ''The Internet's Own Boy'', a documentary about Aaron Swartz, and ''[[We Are Legion]]'', a film about the hacker group "Anonymous"; [[David Segal (politician)|David Segal]], co-founder of [[Demand Progress]]; Peter Eckersley of [[Electronic Frontier Foundation|EFF]]; and [[Sina Khanifar]], website developer for "The Day We Fight Back" and several other activist projects.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} Doctorow and Eckersley indicated they had been close friends of Swartz.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} On February 11, organizers again held an AMA{{cite web|last=Stuckey|first=Daniel|title=How an Anti-NSA Campaign Took Over the Internet|url=http://motherboard.vice.com/blog/how-an-anti-nsa-campaign-took-over-the-internet|work=Motherboard|accessdate=12 February 2014}} and issued the following statement: :Two years ago, reddit and its users joined in fighting back against dangerous Internet censorship legislation during the SOPA protests. You blacked out your websites and started hundreds of creative campaigns to defeat a piece of legislation that threatened freedom on the Internet. :In the last 6 months we've seen that government agencies, namely the NSA and GCHQ and others, have broken laws and twisted legal interpretations to create an infrastructure of mass surveillance of all of us online. This creates a dark form of censorship as people become afraid to speak freely -- and it's one that undermines our security and our right to privacy as well. As users of the Internet, we have a responsibility to defend its freedom.{{cite web|last=Segal|first=David|title=We are "The Day We Fight Back" Organizers, Ask Us Anything|url=https://www.reddit.com/r/IAmA/comments/1xm761/we_are_the_day_we_fight_back_organizers_ask_us/|publisher=Reddit}} ===Inspiration from Aaron Swartz === {{main|Aaron Swartz}} [[File:Aaron Swartz profile.jpg|thumb|right|[[Aaron Swartz]]]] Aaron Swartz was an American activist who founded the online group [[Demand Progress]], known for its campaign against the [[Stop Online Piracy Act]] (SOPA). Swartz, a fellow at Harvard, was arrested by [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology Police Department|MIT police]] after systematically downloading [[academic journal]] articles from [[JSTOR]].{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/joshgerstein/0711/MIT_also_pressing_charges_against_hacking_suspect.html |title=MIT also pressing charges against hacking suspect |first=Josh |last=Gerstein |date=July 22, 2011 |work=Politico |quote=[Swartz's] alleged use of MIT facilities and Web connections to access the JSTOR database ... resulted in two state felony charges for breaking into a 'depository' and breaking & entering in the daytime, according to local prosecutors. }}{{cite court |litigants=Commonwealth v. Swartz |opinion=11-52CR73 & 11-52CR75 |pinpoint=MIT Police Incident Report 11-351 |court=[[Massachusetts District Court|Mass. Dist. Ct.]] |date=nolle prosequi Dec. 16, 2011 |url=http://mitcrimeclub.org/SwartzFilings-state.pdf |quote=Captain [A.P.] and Special Agent Pickett were able to apprehend the suspect at 24 Lee Street.... He was arrested for two counts of Breaking and Entering in the daytime with the intent to commit a felony.... }} The [[US Department of Justice]] charged Aaron Swartz with multiple felonies. He faced a potential penalty of 35 years confinement in a federal penitentiary.{{cite press release |author = US Attorney's Office District of Massachusetts |title = Alleged Hacker Charged With Stealing Over Four Million Documents from MIT Network |url = http://www.justice.gov/usao/ma/news/2011/July/SwartzAaronPR.html |date = July 19, 2011 |accessdate = January 17, 2013 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120526080523/http://www.justice.gov/usao/ma/news/2011/July/SwartzAaronPR.html |archivedate = May 26, 2012 |df = mdy-all }} On January 11, 2013, two days after the prosecution denied his lawyer's second offer of a [[plea bargain]], Swartz was found dead, having hanged himself. {{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-21001452 | title=Aaron Swartz, internet freedom activist, dies aged 26 | publisher=BBC News | date=January 13, 2013 | accessdate=2013-01-13}}{{cite news |title=Aaron Swartz, Tech Prodigy and Internet Activist, Is Dead at 26|url= http://business.time.com/2013/01/13/tech-prodigy-and-internet-activist-aaron-swartz-commits-suicide/ | work=Time|accessdate=January 13, 2013|date=January 13, 2013}} Many commentators viewed the prosecution, which could have imposed a devastating prison term for accessing information in bulk rather than one article at a time, as 'bullying' that ultimately lead to Swartz's death.{{cite web |url=http://lessig.tumblr.com/post/40347463044/prosecutor-as-bully |title=Prosecutor as bully |publisher=Lessig Blog, v2 |first=Lawrence |last=Lessig |date=January 12, 2013 |accessdate=January 12, 2013}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/13/technology/aaron-swartz-internet-activist-dies-at-26.html |title=Internet Activist, a Creator of RSS, Is Dead at 26, Apparently a Suicide |work=[[The New York Times]] |first=John |last=Schwartz |date=January 12, 2013 |accessdate=January 13, 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://bostinno.streetwise.co/2014/01/11/mit-website-hacked-by-anonymous-announces-the-day-we-fight-back/ |title=Anonymous Hacks MIT Website in Memory of Aaron Swartz, Announces 'The Day We Fight Back' |publisher=BostInno |first=Lauren |last=Landry |date=January 11, 2014}} February 11, 2014, the planned day of protest, falls one month after the first anniversary of the death of Aaron Swartz.{{cite news |url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2013/03/11/130311fa_fact_macfarquhar |title=Requiem for a dream: The tragedy of Aaron Swartz |work=[[The New Yorker]] |first=Larissa |last=MacFarquhar |date=March 11, 2013 |quote=[Swartz] wrote a script that instructed his computer to download articles continuously, something that was forbidden by JSTOR's terms of service....  He spoofed the computer's address....  This happened several times.  MIT traced the requests to his laptop, which he had hidden in an unlocked closet.}}{{cite news |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/technology/technology/2013/02/aaron_swartz_he_wanted_to_save_the_world_why_couldn_t_he_save_himself.6.html |title=The Idealist: Aaron Swartz wanted to save the world. Why couldn't he save himself? |work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |first=Justin |last=Peters |page=6 |date=February 7, 2013 |quote=The superseding indictment ... claimed that Swartz had 'contrived to break into a restricted-access wiring closet at MIT.'  But the closet door had been unlocked—and remained unlocked even after the university and authorities were aware that someone had been in there trying to access the school's network. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130210170319/http://www.slate.com/articles/technology/technology/2013/02/aaron_swartz_he_wanted_to_save_the_world_why_couldn_t_he_save_himself.6.html |archivedate=February 10, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-205_162-57563656/co-founder-of-reddit-aaron-swartz-found-dead/ |title=Co-founder of Reddit Aaron Swartz found dead |publisher=CBS News |date=January 12, 2013 |accessdate=January 12, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130113042659/http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-205_162-57563656/co-founder-of-reddit-aaron-swartz-found-dead/ |archivedate=January 13, 2013}} Swartz's brother, Noah Swartz, is "actively organizing" The Day We Fight Back. David Segal said in a statement, {{blockquote|Today the greatest threat to a free Internet, and broader free society, is the National Security Agency's mass spying regime. If Aaron were alive he'd be on the front lines, fighting back against these practices that undermine our ability to engage with each other as genuinely free human beings.{{cite web |url=http://motherboard.vice.com/blog/internet-activists-look-back-at-aaron-swartzs-life-as-the-day-we-fight-back-approaches |title=Internet Activists Look Back at Aaron Swartz's Life as 'The Day We Fight Back' Approaches |work=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]] |series=Motherboard |first=D.J. |last=Pangburn |date=January 13, 2014 |accessdate=January 15, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140115091652/http://motherboard.vice.com/blog/internet-activists-look-back-at-aaron-swartzs-life-as-the-day-we-fight-back-approaches |archivedate=January 15, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://www.net-security.org/secworld.php?id=16199 |title=Privacy advocates announce day of protest against NSA spying |publisher=Help Net Security |date=January 13, 2014 |accessdate=January 15, 2014}}}} In the clip, Swartz comments on [[mass surveillance]], {{blockquote|It is shocking to think that the accountability is so lax that they don't even have sort of basic statistics about how big the spying programme is. If the answer is, 'Oh, we're spying on so many people we can't possibly even count them,' then that's an awful lot of people." Five months after Swartz's death, the scale of a vast global surveillance program would be [[Global surveillance disclosures (2013–present)|revealed]] in great detail through the release of top-secret NSA documents by [[Edward Snowden]]. The film follows director Brian Knappenberger's recent op-ed documentary for ''The New York Times'' titled "Why Care About the NSA?"{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/26/opinion/why-care-about-the-nsa.html |title='Why Care About the N.S.A.? |work=[[The New York Times]] |first=Brian |last=Knappenberger |date=November 25, 2013 |accessdate=January 21, 2014}}}} ==Related events== [[File:"Your world delivered to the NSA" on AT&T building in San Fransisco.jpg|thumb|"Your world delivered ... to the NSA. On AT&T building in SF where whistleblower Mark Klein saw the NSA spying room." Tweeted{{cite web|last=Opsohl|first=Kurt|title=Tweet|url=https://twitter.com/kurtopsahl/status/433429081225310208/photo/1|publisher=Twitter |accessdate=12 February 2014}} by Kurt Opsohl, attorney with the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation|EFF]]; from "The Day We Fight Back" protest in San Francisco, February 11, 2014]] Related demonstrations were scheduled in 15 countries.{{cite news |last=Gabbatt|first=Adam|title=Protesters rally for 'the day we fight back' against mass surveillance|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/feb/11/day-fight-back-protest-nsa-mass-surveillance|accessdate=11 February 2014}} Activities to support the protest took place "from Argentina to Uganda, from Colombia to the Philippines".{{cite web|last=O'Brian|first=Danny|title=Today Is the Day the Internet Fights Back to Protect Privacy|publisher=Gizmodo|accessdate=17 February 2014}} Events included: *Bitbureauet, a Denmark-based think-tank, announced plans for a protest outside the US embassy in Copenhagen, using the slogan "tag internettet tilbage" ('take back the internet').{{cite web|url=https://thedaywefightback.org/events/ |title=A List of Events Happening on The Day We Fight Back |publisher=The Day We Fight Back |date= |accessdate=2014-02-11}}{{cite web|url=http://taginternettettilbage.nu/ |title=Tag internettet tilbage! 11. februar 2014 - Demonstration mod masseovervågning |publisher=Taginternettettilbage.nu |date= |accessdate=2014-02-11}}{{cite web|url=http://taginternettettilbage.nu/pressemeddelelse.pdf |title=Pressemeddelelse : 31 January 2014 |publisher=Taginternettettilbage.nu |accessdate=2014-02-11}} *[[Restore the Fourth]], an American organization, planned a protest outside the AT&T Building in San Francisco that houses [[Room 641A]], the facility operated by AT&T for the U.S. National Security Agency. According to the organization, the protest will feature a speech by [[Mark Klein]], the AT&T technician who publicly exposed the facility in 2006.{{cite web|url=https://restorethefourthsf.com/events/the-day-we-fight-back-against-mass-surveillance/ |title=The Day We Fight Back Against Mass Surveillance |publisher=Restore The Fourth San Francisco Bay Area |date=2013-11-23 |accessdate=2014-02-11}}{{cite journal |url=https://www.wired.com/science/discoveries/news/2006/05/70908 |title=AT&T Whistle-Blower's Evidence |journal=Wired |date=May 17, 2006 |accessdate=February 27, 2009 }}{{cite news | title = The NSA Is Building the Country's Biggest Spy Center (Watch What You Say) | first = James | last = [https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/author/james-bamford/ Bamford] | url = https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2012/03/ff_nsadatacenter/all/1 | newspaper = [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] | date = 15 March 2012 | accessdate = 23 April 2012 }} The EFF has announced plans for an event in Bluffdale, Utah, near the [[Utah Data Center]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rstreet.org/2014/02/10/a-day-to-fight-back/ |title=A Day To Fight Back | R Street Institute | Free Markets. Real Solutions |publisher=Rstreet.org |date=1999-02-22 |accessdate=2014-02-11}} The Rhode Island Coalition to Defend Human and Civil Rights and Rhode Island [[MoveOn.org]] announced a protest outside federal courthouse in Providence.http://www.beaumontenterprise.com/news/article/RI-groups-protest-federal-government-surveillance-5224024.php *The [[Pirate Party of Sweden]] will hold a demonstration in Stockholm with speeches by party founder [[Rick Falkvinge]] and party leader [[Anna Troberg]].{{cite web|url=http://stockholm.piratpartiet.se/2014/02/06/stockholm-demonstrera-med-oss-pa-the-day-we-fight-back/ |title=Stockholm: Demonstrera med oss på The Day We Fight Back |publisher=Piratpartiet Stockholm |date=2014-02-06 |accessdate=2014-02-11}} [[Cryptoparty]]-Austria has announced plans for a rally in Forum Stadtpark in [[Graz]].https://cryptoparty.at/graz graz The [[Software Freedom Law Center]] announced plans to host an event in [[New Delhi]].{{cite web|url=http://sflc.in/events/event/the-day-we-fight-back/ |title=The Day We Fight Back |publisher=Sflc.in |date=2014-02-07 |accessdate=2014-02-11}} *[[KBOO]], an Oregon-based listener-funded radio station, scheduled a day of special programming related to Internet activism.{{cite news |url=http://kboo.fm/thedaywefightback |title=The Day We Fight Back Against Mass Surveillance |publisher=KBOO |date=2014-01-31 |accessdate=2014-02-11}} *In [[Manila]], protestors rallied outside the Supreme Court against the surveillance-related "Philippines 2012 Cybercrime Prevention Act".{{cite web|url=http://www.worldcrunch.com/default/worldwide-protests-against-mass-surveillance/the-day-we-fight-back-nsa-surveillance-snowden/c0s14985/#.UvoKObSIqUk |title=Snapshot Of The World - Feb. 10-17 - All News Is Global |publisher=Worldcrunch.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-11}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thepicturesoftheday.com/ |title=ZUMA Pictures Of The Day: News, Sports, Celeb images and more |publisher=Thepicturesoftheday.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-11}} *A UK-based coalition called "Don't Spy on Us" organized its own protest. The coalition included the [[Open Rights Group]], [[PEN International|English Pen]], [[Liberty]], [[Privacy International]], [[Big Brother Watch]] and [[Article 19]].{{cite web|last=Solon |first=Olivia |url=https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2014-02/11/dont-spy-on-us |title=Don't Spy On Us: It's time to hold politicians to account for mass surveillance (Wired UK) |publisher=Wired.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-02-11}} ==Supporters== Supporting the digital protest was a "broad coalition of activist groups, companies, and online platforms".{{cite news |first=Miles |last=Mogulescu |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/miles-mogulescu/it-can-happen-again-cover_b_4761481.html |title=It Can Happen Again: Covert Government Programs to Discredit Martin Luther King and Other Dissenters Show Dangers of NSA |publisher=The Huffington Post |date= February 10, 2014|accessdate=2014-02-11}} ''The Guardian'' observed that supporters included unlikely bedfellows, citing backing from both [[American Civil Liberties Union]] and the "very conservative" [[FreedomWorks]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/feb/06/nsa-fighting-back-against-surveillence-state |title=Get ready: the day we fight back against mass surveillance is coming |first=Dan |last=Gillmor |publisher=The Guardian |date=2007-09-28 |accessdate=2014-02-11}} Political parties supporting the protest included the US [[Libertarian Party (United States)|National Libertarian Party]], the [[Australian Greens]], the [[Pirate Party of Sweden]], and Ron Paul's [[Campaign for Liberty]].{{cite web |last=Janney |first=Elizabeth |url=http://belair.patch.com/groups/politics-and-elections/p/surveillance-protestors-take-usa-freedom-act-demonstration-online-belair |title=Surveillance Protestors Take 'USA Freedom Act' Demonstration Online - Government - Bel Air, MD Patch |publisher=Belair.patch.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-11}}{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/tech/2014/02/07/protesters-take-to-web-to-address-nsa-surveillance-concerns/ |title=Mass protests planned for Tues over NSA surveillance |publisher=Fox News |date=2014-02-07 |accessdate=2014-02-11}}{{cite news |last=Cowan |first=Paris |url=http://www.itnews.com.au/News/371977,greens-go-black-to-fight-online-surveillance.aspx |title=Greens go black to fight online surveillance - Security - Technology - News |publisher=Itnews.com.au |date= |accessdate=2014-02-11}}{{cite web |first=Paul |last=Wagenseil |url=http://www.tomsguide.com/us/day-fight-back,news-18296.html |title=Facebook Supporting 'Day We Fight Back' Protest – Tom's Guide |publisher=Tomsguide.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-11}} Congressman [[Ted Poe]] (R-TX) has also endorsed the protest.{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/day-we-fight-back-congress-battered-emails-phone-calls-internet-protest-nsa-spying-1554614|title=The Day We Fight Back: Congress Battered With Emails And Phone Calls In Internet Protest Of NSA Spying|date=February 11, 2014|publisher=}} The "most prominent addition" to the protest was the "Reform Government Surveillance" coalition,{{cite news |last=Swartz|first=Jon|title=Tech giants team up in anti-snooping effort|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2013/12/09/google-microsoft-facebook-others-form-reform-government-surveillance-coalition/3914697/|work=USA Today|accessdate=11 February 2014|date=December 9, 2013}} which includes [[AOL]], [[Twitter]], [[LinkedIn]], and [[Yahoo]]. It was not initially clear how the sites would participate.{{cite news |last=Voltz|first=Dustin|title=Coalition of Google, Facebook, and Other Tech Giants Join Mass NSA Protest|url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/technology/coalition-of-google-facebook-and-other-tech-giants-join-mass-nsa-protest-20140210|work=National Journal|accessdate=11 February 2014}} The group sent a letter to President Obama on November 11 and "urged changes that would include a government agreement not to collect bulk data from Internet communications."{{cite news |title='The Day We Fight Back': Top Tech Firms Urge Changes to U.S. Spying|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/day-we-fight-back-top-tech-firms-urge-changes-u-n27866|agency=AP|publisher=NBC News |accessdate=12 February 2014}} On the same day, Google announced its support for the USA Freedom Act, saying "Google recognizes the very real threats that the U.S. and other countries face, but we strongly believe that government surveillance programs should operate under a legal framework that is rule-bound, narrowly tailored, transparent, and subject to oversight."{{cite news |last=Sledge|first=Matt|title=Google Backs Major Effort To Rein In NSA|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/02/11/google-nsa-freedom-act_n_4767621.html|publisher=The Huffington Post|accessdate=12 February 2014|date=February 11, 2014}} [[Matt Simons]], director of social and economic justice at [[ThoughtWorks]], nevertheless said the coalition's support of The Day We Fight Back "rings a little hollow" because of the late date of its announcement and its member's past disclosure of their customers' data to the NSA.{{cite news |url=https://www.theverge.com/2014/2/10/5398638/the-day-we-fight-back-asks-the-internet-to-fight-surveillance|title=The Day We Fight Back: can an internet protest stop the NSA?*|publisher=[[The Verge]]|date=February 10, 2014|first=Adi|last=Robertson}} Groups supporting The Day We Fight Back include the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation|EFF]], the [[ACLU]], [[Freedomworks]], [[Greenpeace]], [[Demand Progress]], [[Human Rights Watch]], the [[Government Accountability Project]],http://www.whistleblower.org/blog/48-2014/3183-today-the-day-we-fight-back-goes-global [[Restore the Fourth]], the [[Free Software Foundation]], and [[Amnesty International]]. Websites supporting the protest included [[Reddit]],{{cite news |last=Wagstaff |first=Keith |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/internet/reddit-tumblr-more-protest-nsa-day-we-fight-back-n26416 |title=Reddit, Tumblr and More Protest NSA With 'Day We Fight Back' |publisher=NBC News |date=2013-11-22 |accessdate=2014-02-11}} [[Tumblr]], [[Wikia]], [[Mozilla]], [[Facebook]], and [[Google]].{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2014/02/11/google-nsa-protests/|title=Google on NSA: We Need Rules, Transparency and Oversight|first=Lorenzo|last=Franceschi-Bicchierai|publisher=}} [[File:TDWFB2.jpg|frameless|right|February 11, 2014]] By February 11, more than 6,000 websites and organizations had signed up to show support by featuring ''The Day We a Fight Back'' banner for 24 hours.{{cite web |title='The day we fight back': 6,000 websites protest surveillance, honor Aaron Swartz|url=http://rt.com/news/activists-internet-protests-fight-440/ |publisher=RT|accessdate=11 February 2014}}{{cite news |last=Rhodan |first=Maya |url=http://swampland.time.com/2014/02/10/the-day-we-fight-back-protests-nsa-surveillance/ |title=NSA Surveillance Protest: 'The Day We Fight Back' | TIME.com |publisher=Swampland.time.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-11}} The Huffington Post released images of various [[Internet meme|memes]] meant to be posted to sites like Facebook and Twitter as part of the event.{{cite news |last=Kleinman|first=Alexis|title=Feb. 11 Is 'The Day We Fight Back' Against NSA Surveillance|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/02/10/the-day-we-fight-back_n_4759693.html |publisher=The Huffington Post|accessdate=10 February 2014|date=February 10, 2014}} Tens of thousands of individuals pledged to make calls and Internet posts supporting surveillance reform.{{cite news |last=Gross|first=Grant|title=More than 4,000 groups sign up to protest the NSA|url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/2095300/more-than-4000-groups-sign-up-to-protest-nsa.html|work=PCWorld|accessdate=10 February 2014}} ==Reaction== By mid-day, organizers said supporters had sent 104,000 emails and made nearly 50,000 calls to Congress. On [[Twitter]], the [[hashtag]] "StopTheNSA" became a 'trending' topic.{{cite web |last=LaCapria|first=Kim|title=#StopTheNSA Trends On Twitter Thanks to The Day We Fight Back |url=http://www.business2community.com/social-buzz/day-fight-back-stopthensa-trends-twitter-0774631|publisher=B2C|accessdate=11 February 2014}} Joining tech companies and public figures, lawmakers voiced support using the online platform, including [[Tom Udall]], [[Jerry Nadler]], [[Rick Larsen]], [[Ron Wyden]], [[Raul M. Grijalva]], [[Mike Honda]], [[Mark Pocan]], [[Alan Grayson]], and [[Rand Paul]].{{cite news |last=Kopan|first=Tal|title=#StopTheNSA lights up Twitter|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2014/02/stopthensa-twitter-103385.html?hp=l6|work=Politico|accessdate=11 February 2014}} Senator [[Bernie Sanders]] (I-VT) posted:
What I worry about is kids growing up in a society where they say 'if I send this email or if I visit this website, then somebody may think I'm a terrorist. I'm not going to talk about this issue, I'm not going to read this book, I'm not going to explore this idea.' I don't want anyone thinking about that. It upsets me very much and is not the kind of free society I think we should be living in.{{cite web |last=Sanders|first=Bernie|title=Tweet|url=https://twitter.com/SenSanders/status/433256403973586944|publisher=Twitter|accessdate=11 February 2014}}
As February 11 drew to a close, ''[[The New York Times]]'' posted a blog titled "The Day the Internet Didn't Fight Back," reporting that "the protest on Tuesday barely registered. [[Wikipedia]] did not participate. Reddit ... added an inconspicuous banner to its homepage. Sites like Tumblr, Mozilla and [[DuckDuckGo]], which were listed as organizers, did not include the banner on their homepages. The eight major technology companies—Google, [[Microsoft]], Facebook, AOL, [[Apple Inc.|Apple]], Twitter, Yahoo and LinkedIn ... only participated Tuesday insofar as having a joint website flash the protest banner."{{cite news |url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/02/11/the-day-the-internet-didnt-fight-back/ |title=The Day the Internet Didn't Fight Back |work=[[The New York Times]] |series=Bits |first=Nicole |last=Perlroth |date=February 11, 2014 |accessdate=March 4, 2014}} ==Notable participants== {{refimprove section|date=February 2014}} {{columns-list|colwidth=22em| * [[ACLU]] * [[Amnesty International]] * [[AOL]] * [[Demand Progress]] * [[Electronic Frontier Foundation|EFF]] * [[Facebook]] * [[Freedomworks]] * [[Greenpeace]] * [[Human Rights Watch]] * [[LinkedIn]] * [[Mozilla]] * [[Reddit]] * [[Restore the Fourth]] * [[Tumblr]] * [[Twitter]] * [[Wikia]] * [[Yahoo]] }} ==See also== * [[Stop Watching Us]] * [[USA Freedom Act]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|Demonstrations and protests relating to the Internet}} * {{official website|https://thedaywefightback.org}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Day We Fight Back, The}} [[Category:2014 protests]] [[Category:Global surveillance]] [[Category:Internet-based and online protests]] [[Category:Protests against mass surveillance]] [[Category:National Security Agency]]

{{Infobox ethnic group |group = Tibetan Canadians |image = |pop = 8,040<ref name="statcan1">{{cite web|url=http://www12.statcan.gc.ca/census-recensement/2016/dp-pd/prof/details/page.cfm?Lang=E&Geo1=PR&Code1=01&Geo2=PR&Code2=01&Data=Count&SearchText=Canada&SearchType=Begins&SearchPR=01&B1=Ethnic%20origin&TABID=1|title=Census Profile. 2016 Census. Statistics Canada Catalogue no. 98-316-X2016001|publisher=Statistics Canada, 2017|location=Ottawa|date=November 29, 2017|accessdate=July 6, 2018}}</ref> |popplace = [[Toronto]] |langs = [[Tibetic languages]], [[Canadian English]], [[Canadian French]] |rels = {{hlist|Majority: [[Tibetan Buddhism]]|Minority: [[Bon]], [[Islam]], [[Christianity]]}}{{cn|date=July 2018}} |related = [[Tibetan people|Tibetans]], [[Tibetan Americans]]}}
Although '''Tibetan Canadians''', or '''Canadians of Tibetan ancestry''', comprise a small portion of Asian [[Canadians]], Canada holds one of the largest concentrations of Tibetans outside Asia. Tibetans began immigrating to Canada as early as the early 1970s.<ref name="macpherson">[http://www.migrationinformation.org/USFocus/display.cfm?ID=693 Global Nomads: The Emergence of the Tibetan Diaspora (Part I)], by Seonaigh MacPherson (University of British Columbia), Anne-Sophie Bentz (Graduate Institute of International and Development Studies), Dawa Bhuti Ghoso</ref>
== Population == In 2016, the Tibetan population in Canada was recorded as being 8,040.<ref name="statcan1"/>
The majority of Tibetan-Canadians live in the [[Toronto]] metropolitan area. In 2016, there were 6,035 Tibetan-Canadians living in the [[Greater Toronto Area]].<ref name="statcan1"/> There is a sizable Tibetan community with Tibetan businesses and restaurants, known as [[Little Tibet (Toronto)|Little Tibet]], in the [[Parkdale, Toronto|Parkdale]] neighborhood in Toronto, in the area bound by Queen St. W. to the north, the Gardiner Expressway to the west and south, and Atlantic Ave. to the east. There is also a growing Tibetan community in South Etobicoke.<ref name=thestar>Loriggio, Paola.[https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2008/05/15/at_home_in_little_tibet.html 'At home' in Little Tibet], ''[[Toronto Star]]''. May 15, 2008.</ref>
== The Displaced Tibetan == Tibetans that have migrated to Canada and other countries have been subjected to a complex and violent history. Being under the rule of the Dalai Lama, Tibet was seen as a contained region on the global scale. This was true between the years 1912 to 1950.<ref name=":03">Logan, J., & Murdie, R. (2016). Home in Canada? The Settlement Experiences of Tibetans in Parkdale, Toronto. ''Journal Of International Migration And Integration'', ''17''(1), 95-113</ref> During the same period of time, this was independent Tibet .
The official religion of Tibet in the 13th century was Buddhism Tibet.<ref name=":1">Dhussa, R. C. (2009). Tibet: A Nation in Exile. American Geographical Society's Focus On Geography, 52(2), 1-6.</ref>
In 1950, China occupied Tibet causing the Tibetan government to be also under Chinese jurisdiction. Throughout the years, culture and religion took an impact from Chinese occupation which was expressed through the ruination of religious statues of Tibet and the destruction of buildings that represented the Tibetan culture <ref name=":03"/>
In 1959, around 87,000 are killed during the Chinese occupation.<ref name=":1" /> Tibetans that practiced their religion were killed. At least 80 000 Tibetans and the Dalai Lama left Tibet to Nepal but were denied access.<ref name=":23">Raska, J. (2016). Humanitarian Gesture: Canada and the Tibetan Resettlement Program, 1971-5. ''Canadian Historical Review'', ''97''(4), 546-575.</ref> Then they found refuge in India.<ref name=":03"/> India took them, however had difficulty to give imperative services and help needed to Tibetan refugees. However, there were more migration patterns towards India in the 1980s and 1990s.<ref name=":23"/>
During the United Nations Convention on the Status of Refugees in 1951, India did not sign this convention. This entailed that Tibetans living in India had little rights and hence tried to find another place for resettlement.<ref name=":03"/>
=== Nomadic Lifestyle === Tibetan’s nomadic life style was notably present when China had a significant control over the geographical area of Tibet, the Chinese occupation. Therefore, Tibetans started to move and not submitting to this control.<ref name=":1" /> This means Tibetans were being displaced within their borders.
==Tibetan resettlement to Canada==
In 1970 and 1971, 240 Tibetan refugees settled into Canada from India. The resettlement of Tibetan refugees was viewed by the Canadian government as a pilot project to evaluate what the country would do in the future regarding refugee aid. It was after a direct plea from the [[Dalai Lama]] to Prime Minister [[Lester B. Pearson]] in 1966 that launched Canada's slow process to bring 60 families into their country. The first Tibetans to arrive from the resettlement group were Tsering Dorjee Wangkhang and Jampa Dorjee Drongotsang when they landed in Toronto on October 15, 1970. The two settled in [[Batawa]], Ontario where the first Tibetan community was planned to be located. Wangkhang and Drongotsang both started working at the Bata shoe factory. Factory owner Thomas Bata had gone to India, one of the countries where Tibetans were exiled, and took the initiative to employ three to four refugees in his company.<ref>Dubinsky, Karen, et al. Canada and the Third World: Overlapping Histories. University of Toronto Press, 2016.</ref>
In 2007, a two-year immigration program to bring 2,000 Tibetan refugees to Canada was organized by Prime Minister [[Stephen Harper]] after a plea by the Dalai Lama. The first 21 Tibetans flew from India to Vancouver International Airport and were expected to settle into the [[Toronto]], [[Ottawa]], [[Vancouver]] and [[Sunshine Coast (British Columbia)|Sunshine Coast]] areas.<ref name="Bradley, A. 2010">Bradley, A. (2010). Beyond Borders: Cosmopolitanism and Family Reunification for Refugees in Canada. International Journal Of Refugee Law, 22(3), 379-403.</ref>
== New Home in Canada and Integration Process == Canada originally declined Tibetan refugees to settle as a group, however this changed with consultations and national meeting with the Prime minister, Pierre Elliot Trudeau. This involved the one of the previous high commissioners to India called James George. James Gorge’s impact on Pierre Elliot Trudeau helped immigration officials to be more lenient with refuge policies for Tibetans.<ref name=":23"/>
In the 1960s, the Canadian government accepts Tibetan refugees under a few conditions. These conditions were set under the Tibetan Refugee program. This was an experimental program that would let 228 Tibetans enter Canada quickly and at a lower cost.<ref name=":23" />
It took a decade for the first Tibetans migrants to set foot in Canada. The Canadian government officials did not want Tibetans to settle in a group but on individual basis and family basis. This means that only young families and single people coming as laborers were approved to seek refuge in Canada. Additionally, Canadian immigration officials were concerned about Tibetans nomadic lifestyles and establishing/settling themselves as a group. This would pose a challenge on the integration process. If group settlement had been approved, the integration process would have been much more difficult and permanency of integration would also be a challenge for new comers and pose issues on the governmental level.<ref name=":23" /> Canadian immigration officials were worried that it would pose problems. Such problems were isolation and dependence within members of the same ethnic community. Additionally, learning one of the official languages of Canada was another problem that could arise and could affect integration directly (Logan & Murdie, 2014). Moreover, immigration officials chose younger Tibetan immigrants over older immigrant groups because integration would be easier regarding the process of learning one of the official languages. Therefore, finding a job and reaching out if one needs help or services would also be affected positively.<ref name=":32">Batarseh, R. C. (2016). Inside/Outside the Circle: From the Indochinese Designated Class to Contemporary Group Processing. Refuge (0229-5113), 32(2), 54-66.</ref>
Tibetan immigrants were also selected from towns and villages because knowing their nomadic lifestyle, immigrant officials wanted Tibetans that had sedentary patterns. Tibetans also needed to have a certain level of high education.<ref name=":32" />
Integration was facilitated through “group processing” which involves refugees and the state work together to aid resettlement into Canada.<ref name=":32" />
== Parkdale, Toronto == The neighbourhood of [[Parkdale, Toronto|Parkdale]] in [[Toronto]] contains the largest concentration of Tibetan immigrants and refugees in Canada. As of the [[Canada 2006 Census|2006 Canadian Census]], around 11% of Parkdale residents were of Tibetan ethnicity, comprising 1,985 persons (62% of Toronto's total Tibetan population and 42% of Tibetans in all of Canada).<ref name=":03"/> According to global population estimates, this makes the Parkdale Tibetan community the largest outside of Tibet and its surrounding area.<ref>https://www.migrationpolicy.org/article/global-nomads-emergence-tibetan-diaspora-part-i</ref>
Most of the housing in the area consists of high-rise apartment buildings and single-family homes. Compared to much of the Toronto core, rent prices in Parkdale are affordable, and the area provides many amenities and services to recent immigrants and at-risk populations. Additionally, public transit offers accessibility to the city centre of Toronto.<ref name=":03" />
=== Culture and Community === Parkdale's existing Tibetan community and cultural institutions encourage the continued immigration of Tibetans to the neighbourhood, with 64% of Tibetan immigrants citing the existing presence of other Tibetans as a major factor in their decision to settle in the area.<ref name=":03" /> [[Little Tibet, Toronto|Little Tibet]] is centered around a series of blocks on [[Queen Street West]], consisting of a number of Tibetan restaurants and shops with diverse influences from India, Nepal and China.
=== Family Reunification Concerns === Within Parkdale, a significant concern among Tibetan Canadian families is reunification with their relatives. Tibetans living in Canada that have already obtained permanent residency have found difficulty bringing their family members into Canada. Many of the relatives that have been unable to come to Canada live in Nepal and India. Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC) states that the Nepalese government is blocking Tibetan peoples that found refuge in Nepal after 1989 from exiting the country. India imposes that Tibetans must have a valid Identity Certificate to exit the country, and the process of obtaining this document can take several years.<ref name="Bradley, A. 2010"/>
==Notable Tibetan Canadians== *[[Bhutila Karpoche]], member of the [[Legislative Assembly of Ontario]] and the first person of Tibetan descent ever elected to public office in North America
== See also == {{Portal|Canada|Tibet}} * [[Tibetan Americans]] * [[Tibet]] * [[Tibetan people]] * [[World Tibet News]]
